message_1: A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 5 minutes. Initially, it contains 4000 nuclei. Calculate the number of nuclei that will remain after 20 minutes.
message_2:
To calculate the remaining number of nuclei after a certain amount of time, we can use the formula:

N(t) = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where N(t) is the number of nuclei remaining after time t, N0 is the initial number of nuclei, t is the time elapsed, and T is the half-life of the isotope.

In this case, N0 = 4000, t = 20 minutes, and T = 5 minutes. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

N(20) = 4000 * (1/2)^(20/5)

N(20) = 4000 * (1/2)^4

N(20) = 4000 * (1/16)

N(20) = 250

So, after 20 minutes, there will be 250 nuclei remaining.
